author: jeffrey.downard
title: Smart Contracts and the Law
description: 如何将智能合约与法律相结合？

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea is not new and it has been funded in previous campaign and the actual Campaign Brief describes the direction in which the proposal should go - "Dapp proposals should cover foundational Registry solutions".

The proposal, as it is presented, doesn't fit into the challenge objectives.
f6_assessments.q1:
The activities presented in the proposal have less to do with the activities necessary to build a DApp into the Cardano blockchain (workshops, youtube channel etc.). 

The other information provided, given the direction of this proposal, are not relevant for the implementation.

The proposal is written in a vague manner (how a document written in "natural language" looks like?) thus make it unclear for an outsider about what is to be achieved. For me it looks like a mix of visual content creation and a wish for a DApp creation.

The budget is broken down into items but some of them are presented in a vague manner (what is the difference between "Development of (..) a design for a dApp to process the clauses in Plutus and Marlowe" and "Design for a beta version of a dApp to process the clauses in Plutus and Marlowe" items?)
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer is not aware of any risks and challenges relevant to a successful implementation of the project.
In conclusion, the progress of this proposal is hard to assess.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks to solve the problem of how to avoid and arbitrate legal disputes by creating templates and a model dApp for binding arbitration which partially aligns with the challenge goal but is not a foundational registry solution listed in the challenge. 
The proposal does a good job of articulating the value to Cardano ecosystem,
The proposal could be improved by articulating how the solution scales to address future challenges, providing key metrics and goals that more closely align with the challenge, and either selecting another challenge (Miscellaneous) or more closely aligning with this challenge's goals.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal articulates the feasibility aspects of evidence of experience (website), team composition, budget is broken down and reasonable (project management fees on the high side as a percentage of total budget), realistic timetable and plan, and detailed technical explanation of the solution.
The proposal's feasibility could be improved by additional funding plan  (phase 2 & 3 probably funded by future Catalyst funding rounds but not stated) and a challenges and risks section.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal includes a roadmap, milestones, time horizon, a clear understandable description of the targeted problem, and a detailed description of the solution that addresses the problem.
To improve the proposal include metrics/KPIs to measure proposal success.

f6_assessments.q0:
fundamentally it is unclear why a binding arbitration function would be needed in a smart contract.
If the execution of a contract clause is somehow disputable, it is not suitable for smart contract coding. therefore, it is unclear how this proposal answers to the stated goal of the Brief: "Dapp proposals should cover foundational Registry solutions, namely:

National ID & Civil Registry, Property Registration, Medical & Vaccination, Education Census, Revenue Service, Business Incorporations, Elections Voting, Customs & Border Control, Criminal Records, Employment Census, Vehicle Registration, Licensing & Certifications."
f6_assessments.q1: this definition of success: "A workshop with more than thirty active participants drawn from the legal and developer communities. Three integrated video tutorials on the use of provisions for choice of law and jurisdiction and binding arbitration clauses in smart contracts. A set of templates for smart agreements written in both natural language and Plutus." is clearly achievable by this team.
f6_assessments.q2: the presence or absence of publically auditable material by month 3 gives the community the ability to audit the progress to success, which, in turn, is defined as: "A workshop with more than thirty active participants drawn from the legal and developer communities. Three integrated video tutorials on the use of provisions for choice of law and jurisdiction and binding arbitration clauses in smart contracts. A set of templates for smart agreements written in both natural language and Plutus."

f6_assessments.q0: This is an awesome idea and a fantastic proposal. With varying legal traditions in the developing world, how is the proposal seeking to integrate such in smart contract. That is my only little concern. This is great and clear problem identification. It really addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: Great team experience. The proposal has a well-structured phase and I think it is practical to implement. Though KPIs are left out and metric to measure adoption.
f6_assessments.q2: There is a well-defined success. Also, the budget is detailed and associated with deliverables. I think the community should support this as it would be beneficial
